sentences.sentence: On the next day the old man, who was in fact the wisest magician in the city, came in and frowned( 皱着眉头 ) at his slave( 奴隶 ).
Then he said, “In a forest close to the gate of this city there are three pieces of gold.
One is white gold, another is yellow gold, and the gold of the third one is red.
Today you will bring me the piece of white gold, and if you do not bring it back, I will beat you a hundred times.
Go quickly, and at sunset( 日落 ) I will be waiting for you at the door of the garden.
Make sure that you bring the white gold, or bad things will happen to you, because you are my slave( 奴隶 ), and I have bought you for the price of a bowl of sweet wine.”
And then he covered the eyes of the Star-Child with the silk ribbon( 绸带 ), led him through the garden, and opened the little door with his stone ring, leaving him in the street.
The Star-Child went out of the gate of the city, and into the forest, where the Magician had told him to go.
Now this forest was very beautiful to look at from the outside.
It seemed to be full of singing birds and of sweet-smelling flowers, and the Star-Child entered it gladly.
Yet its beauty was only on the outside, for inside it was full of branches( 树枝 ) covered with thorns( （植物的）刺 ).
The thorns( （植物的）刺 ) pierced( 刺破 ) his skin and made him bleed, and making his way through the forest was very painful.
To make matters worse, he could not find the piece of white gold which the Magician had spoken of, no matter how hard or how long he looked.
He searched from morning until noon, and from noon until sunset( 日落 ), but still he did not find the piece of white gold.
At sunset( 日落 ) he turned back, crying bitterly( 伤心地 ), because he knew what would happen when he returned to the Magician without the gold.
But when he had reached the edge of the forest, he heard something or someone crying.
The sound came from nearby, but he could not tell where.
It sounded like someone in pain.
And forgetting his own sorrow( 伤心事 ), he ran toward the sound.
There he saw a little Rabbit caught in a trap( 陷阱 ) set by a hunter( 猎人 ).
The Star-Child took pity on the Rabbit, and set it free.
Then he said to it, “I am only a slave( 奴隶 ), and yet I can give you freedom.”
The Rabbit answered him, and said: “You have given me freedom, but what can I give you in return?”
And the Star-Child replied, “I am looking for a piece of white gold, and cannot find it anywhere.
If I do not bring it to my master( 主人 ), he will beat me.”
“Come with me,” said the Rabbit.
“I will lead you to it, because I know where it is hidden.”
So the Star-Child went with the Rabbit, and in a hole in a great oak-tree( 橡树 ) he saw the piece of white gold.
He was filled with( 充满 ) joy( 喜悦 ), and took it, and said to the Rabbit, “You have repaid( 回报 ) me several times over for saving you, and I owe( 欠 ) you many thanks.”
“No,” answered the Rabbit, “I just did what I could to help you, because you helped me.”
The Rabbit ran off quickly, and the Star-Child made his way back toward the city.
Now at the gate of the city there was a seated beggar( 乞丐 ).
His clothes were torn( 破烂的 ) and dirty, and his face looked tired and hungry.
And when he saw the Star-Child coming, he called out and said, “Give me some money, or I will die of hunger.
They have chased( 驱逐 ) me out of the city, and there is no one who has pity on me.”
“But I have only one coin in my pocket,” answered the Star-Child.
“And if I do not bring it to my master( 主人 ) he will beat me, because I am his slave( 奴隶 ).”
But the beggar( 乞丐 ) looked so hungry, and so tired, and so unfortunate( 不幸的 ) that the Star-Child took pity on the beggar( 乞丐 ), and gave him the piece of white gold.
When the Star-Child returned to the Magician’s house, the Magician opened the door, and asked him, “Do you have the piece of white gold?”
The Star-Child answered, “I do not have it.”
The Magician grabbed( 抓住 ) him, and beat him.
Then he gave him an empty plate( 盘子 ), and said, “Eat.”
After this he gave him an empty cup, and said, “Drink.”
Then he sent him once again into the prison( 牢笼 ).
